figureCitation.captionText: Fig. 9. Euphoriomyces spp. A–C. E. gillerforsii (Huggert) I.I.Tav. A–B. Paired mature thalli, with unicellular secondary appendage labelled in B (sa). C. Detail of perithecial apex with labelled extra cell w 4. – D–E. E. huggertii T.Majewski. D. Mature thallus with labelled primary appendage (pa). E. Paired mature thalli. – F–G. E. liodivorus (Huggert) I.I.Tav. Mature thalli. Scale bars: A–C = 20 µm; D–G = 50 µm. Photographs from slides ZMUC C-F-124079 (A–C), ZMUC C-F-123294 (D–E), ZMUC C-F- 124158 (F), and ZMUC C-F-124138 (G).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Mycologia Memoirs 9: 218 ( Tavares 1985 )
. – Basionym :
Amphimyces liodivorus Huggert, Svensk Botanisk Tidskrift
67: 240 ( Huggert 1973 )
[MB#308662]. –

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Type : “Tl, Kiruna , Kurravaara village,
12.VIII.1971
, S.-O. Ulefors (L.H. 761),
on
Liodes (sic) puncticollis Th.
( Holotype )”; UME . [ Sweden ]

subSubSection.paragraph: Thalli up to 200 µm long from foot to apex of furthest perithecia. Receptacle consisting of 7–12 superposed cells, dividing bilaterally into secondary appendages, some of them giving rise to antheridia, or up to 8 perithecia, the later on the same side. [Detailed descriptions: Santamaria 1991, 2003]

Occurs on
Leiodes
(Col. Leiodidae ) from Sweden ( type ), Spain ( Santamaria 1989 ), United Kingdom ( Weir & Beakes 1993 ), Slovakia ( Rossi & Máca 2006 ), Italy and Bulgaria (
Rossi et al. 2019a
).

On
Leiodes badia (Sturm, 1807)
( Col. Leiodidae )

First record from Denmark . The precise description of some so-called “curious thalli” ( Santamaria 2003: 265–266 ) corresponds to what, according to Danish thalli studied, seems to be the most typical for this species. These larger forms are found on legs and tarsi whereas the smaller thalli are from elytra.
